Leaps into freezing river water to save a stranger's life despite personal turmoil.
Sits silently, cold and gloomy, ignoring others while preoccupied with his own problems after the rescue.
Shows surprise and openness when Clarence reveals he saved him from suicide.
Is sitting cold, gloomy, and drunk, preoccupied by his near suicide and his unsolved problems.
Shows surprise when Clarence reveals he saved him from suicide.
Responds to Clarence’s odd behavior with casual interest and light humor without hostility.
Rubs his head to clear his mind and tries to make sense of the confusing situation instead of reacting negatively.
Humors Clarence's angel story with mild sarcasm but engages in conversation.
Makes a self-deprecating statement about being worth more dead than alive.
Interrupts Clarence's encouragement and dismisses his help harshly.
Annoyed and savagely tells Clarence to shut up and go away.
Expresses bewilderment and sarcasm when interacting with Clarence, shows frustration and annoyance, doubts his own worth and impact.
Humors Clarence reluctantly and engages in conversation despite inner turmoil, showing some social adaptability.
Expresses feelings of despair and wishes he'd never been born.
Interacts with Clarence in a curious, somewhat playful manner despite his dejected mood (e.g., cocking his head, favoring his deaf ear, asking Clarence to speak into the deaf ear).
Expresses a desire to have never been born, showing emotional despair and lack of confidence in life’s value.
Responds curiously and attentively to Clarence's explanation, showing openness and engagement.
Lightly jokes with Clarence about flying without wings, showing friendly and playful interaction.
Expresses confusion and puzzlement without frustration or anger, indicating tolerance and good-naturedness in a confusing situation.
Quickly encourages Clarence to get dressed and go with him, displaying cooperative and inclusive behavior.
Quickly notices physical changes (lip no longer bleeding, clothes dry) and verbalizes confusion about recent events, showing awareness and questioning reality.
Attempts to gather himself and take initiative to dress and leave with Clarence.
When noticing car is gone and tree undamaged, he expresses uncertainty but accepts the strange situation with some openness.
Approaches the owner politely to inquire about his car and acknowledges the mistake about the tree.
Responds to the owner's sharp and dismissive tone with bewilderment rather than anger or retaliation.
Puts his arm around Clarence and continues amiably despite confusion and subtly hostile interaction with the owner.
Invites Clarence and Nick to join him at the bar and offers friendly drink order interaction despite Nick's impatience
Casually initiates conversation with the bartender, tries to inquire about Martini despite Nick's impatience.
Agrees to order a double bourbon quickly under pressure.
Soothes Clarence reassuringly to Nick, indicating acceptance of Clarence despite his odd behavior.
Shows concern by asking Clarence if he has a place to sleep or money, demonstrating care for his wellbeing.
Advises Clarence not to mention angels to Nick to avoid awkwardness, showing sensitivity to others' feelings.
Soothes Clarence by reassuring Nick to treat him the same way and tries to understand Clarence's situation calmly and thoughtfully.
Tries to discreetly prevent Clarence from mentioning angels to avoid awkwardness with Nick, showing social awareness and tact.
Expresses confusion and curiosity about Clarence’s age and situation, indicating a willingness to learn and engage.
Leaps up horrified and goes over to help Gower after he is humiliated and thrown out by Nick and his bouncers.
Addresses Nick calmly and tries to understand what is wrong instead of escalating the confrontation.
Leaps up and goes over to support and recognize Mr. Gower despite the hostile situation.
Appears bewildered and unable to effectively confront Nick or change the situation as Gower is roughly treated and thrown out.
Engages curiously and patiently with Clarence, asks sincere questions about his identity and what is happening.
Attempts to hold on to his identity, insists on returning to his wife and family despite confusing circumstances.
Becomes furious and tells Clarence to shut up, showing frustration and impatience.
Rapidly searches his pockets for identification when told he has no identity, showing quick response to a confusing situation.
Rejects Clarence's explanation and insists on returning home, displaying emotional determination but lack of acceptance of new information.
Furious and dismissive toward Clarence, calling him crazy and screwy, showing a loss of control and impatience.
Recognizes Violet Bick among those being arrested and speaks up for her to the police.
Tries to engage the cop to get information about the Building and Loan.
Does not intervene strongly or resist the police pushing him aside.
Calls his friend Ernie and relies on him to take him home despite Ernie being harsher than before.
Recognizes the dramatic decline of his beloved town and the closure of the Building and Loan, attempts to gather information by questioning a cop and calling a taxi driver.
Shows surprise and confusion but quickly moves to act (getting a taxi) rather than freeze or panic.
Does not resist or escalate situation when shoved aside by the cop, stays focused on his goal.
Appears disoriented when stating 'I'm off my nut' but still directs Ernie clearly and insists on going home.
Insists Ernie drive him home because Zuzu is sick, shows concern for family.
Is exasperated when Ernie does not recognize him, but does not lose temper, remains focused on getting home.
Keeps calm despite being misunderstood and followed by police, demonstrates trustworthiness and sincerity in his demeanor.
Confidently instructs the taxi driver Ernie and insists on going home despite confusion, demonstrating determination and situational awareness.
Fails to recognize that Ernie does not know him and that his information is incorrect, indicating potential confusion or disorientation.
Yells out for his family in an abandoned, ruined house, showing genuine concern and emotional vulnerability.
Rushes toward Bert the policeman relieved at his arrival, openly expressing trust and reliance.
Approaches a damaged, seemingly abandoned house despite its foreboding appearance, calling out to his family emotionally and persistently.
Ignores Clarence's rational statement that his children are not there and insists on searching for them.
Rushes toward Bert, the police officer, showing relief and seeking help.
Struggles to explain the situation to Bert and Ernie, tries to get help and protect Clarence, insists on going to his mother's house despite confusion.
Struggles to explain the strange situation and seeks help despite confusion, showing effort to manage a confusing crisis.
Immediately reacts to being threatened with violence by trying to run and escape, showing presence of mind and self-preservation.
Persistently seeks help and shelter from his mother despite her cold rejection and suspicion.
Appears vulnerable and sincere when pleading for assistance genuinely concerned for himself and others.
Tries to connect with mother by mentioning shared acquaintances to gain trust.
Runs up to the house and persistently tries to gain entry despite cold and suspicious reception.
Appears desperate and pleads for help but fails to convince his mother who suspects him of lying and refusing to open the door.
Attempts to use logic to understand the strange situation he is in, trying to ground himself in facts like knowing where Martini lives.
Appears stunned, emotionally chaotic, and confused when faced with the disappearance of Bailey Park and the new reality.
Wanders uncertainly among the tombstones, looking frightened and unsure, indicating a sense of being lost and not in control of the situation.
Defends the honor of his deceased brother Harry passionately, insisting on the truth about his heroism.
Desperately seeks information about Mary, showing deep concern for her well-being.
Grabs and shakes Clarence by the collar, becomes violent and shouts in frustration and desperation.
Watches Mary with concern and desperation, calls out to her repeatedly trying to get her attention and help.
Catches Mary by the arms and holds on tightly as she struggles to break free.
Pleadingly asks Mary for help and expresses emotional need for her and their kids.
Runs after Mary immediately upon seeing her in distress, tries to get her attention and communicate urgently.
Grabs Mary tightly trying to stop her as she tries to escape, showing determination and focus in a crisis.
Fails to calm Mary or effectively de-escalate the situation; she breaks away and runs, which could show a lack of control over the interaction.
Enters a crowded bar in a distressed state, shouting for Mary and causing uproar, potentially losing situational control.
Desperately searching and calling for Clarence to get back to his wife and kids, showing concern and urgency.
Recognizes people in the crowd and calls out that Mary is his wife, showing attachment and sincerity.
Prays desperately to live again, showing vulnerability and hope.
Joyfully recognizes Zuzu's petals and shares the joyous moment with Bert, embracing him.
Greets townspeople warmly with 'Merry Christmas!' as he runs through the town, expressing genuine joy and friendliness.
Pounds on Potter's office window wishing him 'Merry Christmas' despite their antagonistic relationship, showing goodwill and sincerity.
Notices the changed town sign, recognizes the restoration of Bedford Falls, and warmly interacts with townspeople while running through the town.
Shows triumph and optimism after seeing his wrecked car but quickly continues on without hesitation.
Pounds on Potter's office window and cheekily says 'Merry Christmas, Mr. Potter!' before running off.
Greets bank examiner warmly and shakes his hand despite bad news.
Responds to potential arrest news with humor and cheer, saying 'Isn't it wonderful? Merry Christmas!'
Runs eagerly to find his wife and children, showing concern and love.
Kisses and lovingly replaces the banister knob that broke in his hand.
Expresses affectionate delight at being with his children, saying 'I could eat you up!'
Hugs children tightly and shows sincere concern about their mother’s whereabouts.
Crushes Zuzu to him warmly, shows joy and relief at her health.
Embraces Mary fiercely and tearfully, expresses sincere affection and emotional openness.
Carries children on his back and participates in family celebration.
Comforts and checks on Zuzu, showing attentiveness and care.
Responds to the excitement with joyful, confident expressions and quickly follows Mary’s lead.
Carries children on his back and positions himself obediently as Mary directs, showing cooperation but limited autonomous initiative.
Protects Zuzu from the crowd while overwhelmed by townspeople's generosity and crying as he greets them by name.
Gives money to Violet Bick for her trip to New York.
Receives gratitude from townspeople who say they wouldn't have a roof over their head without him.
Holds Zuzu in his arms tenderly while looking at a meaningful inscription in a book from a friend, acknowledging the value of friendship.
Receives affectionate greetings and support from community members and family, indicating trust and goodwill he has built.
Successfully rallies the community to contribute money and resolve the financial crisis, demonstrating leadership and problem-solving under pressure.
Responds calmly and gratefully to the gesture of friends and family, showing emotional intelligence alongside practical action.
Holds Zuzu in his arms, focusing on a sentimental moment rather than the immediate financial concern.
Smiles warmly at Zuzu, affirms her words kindly, and affectionately acknowledges Clarence with a wink and words of encouragement.
